turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 78-1870, Whirlpool Corporation against the Secretary of Labor.
Mr. Mann, I think you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
My name is Robert Mann.
I represent the petitioner, Whirlpool Corporation, in this proceeding.

This case raises a question of statutory interpretation, and specifically, whether under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Congress intended to confer certain job security rights upon employees who might refuse to work because of perceived safety hazards.

The Secretary of Labor, in 1973, published a regulation purporting to interpret the act, and stating in the regulation that, as a general rule, the legislative history and the act itself indicated that Congress did not intend to create job security rights within the context of OSHA for employees who might refuse to work because of perceived safety hazards.

Within the interpretative regulation, however, but without citing any legislative history or other source, the Secretary of Labor hypothesized situations which might give rise to such job security provisions if an employee refused work in imminent danger conditions, when resort to the normal enforcement procedures were not available.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Mann, the act does give the Secretary the authority to promulgate and enforce standards to eliminate hazards, does it not?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was there any rulemaking notice and comment in connection with this interpretative regulation?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, there was not, Your Honor.
It was published as an interpretative regulation, and not as a rulemaking or legislative type regulation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So it's a Swift against Wickham-type inquiry?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I believe so; yes, Your Honor.

Whirlpool Corporation agrees with the Secretary that the legislative history of the act, and the act itself, clearly demonstrate that it was not Congress' intent to legislate job security provisions within the scope of the Occupational Safety and Health Act, except perhaps in connection with the protection of employees to invoke the procedures of the act.

However, it is our position, and we believe the facts of this case demonstrate, that that type of exception would not exist in this case, since the work refusal occurred outside the scope or context of any attempt to invoke the statutory procedures.
The case arose in June and July of 1974.
It arose at Whirlpool's Marion, Ohio, plant.

And on the night -- on the day shift of June 28th, 1974, an employee who was working at that plant, on a normal maintenance assignment on the overhead guard screen in the plant, fell between two panels of the screen and sustained fatal injuries.
Following that accident, Whirlpool notified OSHA of the fatality.
And on July 1st, 1974, an OSHA inspector conducted an inspection in relation to the accident.
He informed management at the conclusion of his inspection that he felt the accident was a result of a mechanical failure, an unforeseeable accident.
On July 7th, 1974, two other maintenance employees who were --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Mann --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- in what respect was there a mechanical failure?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: As the administrative hearing developed later, Your Honor, it appeared two bolts, holding together portions of the screen, failed, and caused the screen to separate at one point; and the employee stepped through the separation.
That was brought out in the subsequent citation proceeding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It doesn't sound very mechanical to me.
But it's -- maybe it's just the wrong term.
You certainly picked rather an unsympathetic set of facts for your case, didn't you?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, that's true, Your Honor.
I didn't pick the facts, but those are the facts.
And we candidly admit that they are the facts.
On June -- July 7th --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Whatever the facts, counsel, isn't the central question in this case whether this action must be taken by the Secretary through traditional rulemaking, or whether it can be done by regulations promulgated by the Secretary?
Is, or is not, that the central question?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That is not -- that question has not been the central question in the litigation, Your Honor.

The question, the central question, in the litigation has been whether or not the Secretary's interpretation of the act is in accordance with the legislative intent compiled by Senator Williams in his legislative booklet.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Secretary's intent in doing what?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: In the interpretation of the act to provide protections for employees who refuse work assignments.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You would agree, wouldn't you, that the Secretary could perhaps go further, had he promulgated regulations as the statute authorizes him to do?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, the Secretary's authorization to promulgate regulations under the statute exists with respect to the promulgation of standards, uniform standards, of course; and also, under Section 8(g), publication of regulations governing his own responsibilities under the act.
We do not read the act to provide him plenary regulatory authority to, in effect, issue legislative-type regulations under the act.
And I don't believe the Secretary has contended that this particular regulation is a legislative-type regulation.

He is attempting to interpret Section 11(c) of the act to find that under certain circumstances an employee would have a right to refuse a work assignment without regard to the employment consequences of that refusal.
On July 7th, two employees approached their supervision and asked to be relieved of guard screen duty.
They were denied in their request, and on July 9th, one of the two employees contacted the OSHA area director for the region and spoke with him about the guard screen.
Prior to that contact, of course, the OSHA People had conducted their inspection, and as it turned out later, had already decided to issue a citation with respect to the guard screen system.
The citation was not, of course, however, received by Whirlpool until the 12th or 13th of July.

On the evening shift of July 10th, a supervisor accompanied the two complaining employees to a section of overhead guard screen; climbed up to the guard screen, the supervisor did, and physically walked across the guard screen for from 10 to 15 minutes, approximately 800 feet in length, to physically demonstrate to these two employees that the screen they were to work on that evening was safe.
Following that physical demonstration, he asked the two employees to clean some materials which had fallen on the guard screen, from the guard screen; and they refused.
They were subsequently issued a disciplinary warning, lost four hours pay by being suspended, and thus generated this particular litigation.
Both employees returned to work the following day, and have continued to work on the--one of them has continued to work on the guard screen to date; the other apparently is in another position.

At no time throughout this proceeding has the Secretary of Labor or his delegate attempted in any way to initiate any type of imminent danger proceeding, as is contemplated under Section 13 of the Act.
Nor, so far as we know, have the complaining employees attempted to initiate such a proceeding on their own, as is their right under Section 13 of the act.

The Secretary of Labor's position under this particular set of facts is to have processed this case through the normal enforcement channels of citation, hearing, and ultimate decision by the Occupation Safety and Health Review Commission.
The complaint was filed.

The Federal District Court for the Northern District of Ohio ruled in the case that the Secretary's interpretation of the regulation -- of the act--was so inconsistent, so clearly inconsistent with the legislative history and the act itself that he felt he had no choice but to reject the Secretary's interpretation and dismiss the complaint.
The Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This was on the theory it was a strike-with-pay approach?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I believe the district court's view was that it was tantamount to a strike-with-pay approach; it was a type of approach that had been rejected by Congress, both in connection with the strike-with-pay issue and in connection with the administrative-shutdown issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The district court found, did it not, that these employees had a genuine fear of death or physical injury?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: The court did find that, Your Honor; yes, he did.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that the danger was real?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He found that the danger was real.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that they lacked any alternative?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He did not find that they lacked any alternative, in the sense that they were precluded from using the normal enforcement procedures of the act, or the extraordinary enforcement procedures of the act under Section 13.
He made no finding on that point.
And we think that that point is crucial in this -- in the facts of this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I take it your position is that even if they had utilized these alternative procedures, they were supposed to work on the job while these procedures were being employed?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, Your Honor, that is not our position.
The Secretary, I think, in his brief has mischaracterized our position on that point.
It's our view that any employee under constitutional law, certainly under statutory law, has a right to withdraw from a dangerous situation on a work site.
The question in the case is not whether or not he has a right to withdraw.
Whirlpool freely concedes that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean, he can keep his job?
He can keep his job -- he can withdraw and keep his job, but he just won't be paid?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, the question of his job security and pay, we feel that Congress intended to leave for regulation to other statutes; except in a case, perhaps, where the employee would leave his job for the purpose of invoking the procedures available under OSHA.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then, OSHA covers that, I suppose?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: If -- yes, I think Section 11 --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what is your position, then?
Suppose he employs these other mechanisms.
Say he files with OSHA, and says it's very dangerous.
And he says, until they do something about it, I'm not going to work.
What is your right with respect to him?
Could you suspend him and dock him some pay?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Your Honor, the facts of this case don't present that situation.

But I think hypothetically, in a case-by-case analysis, the Court could determine that the employee might be protected to the extent he is in the process of invoking or participating in the procedures.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, let's assume that it's perfectly clear that he's -- he's called them on the phone, or written them a letter, or something, and OSHA says, we'll be out day after tomorrow.
And he says, well -- he says to his employers, "Until these people come and inspect and do something about this, I'm not going to work."
And -- what's your response?
Could you fire him at that point?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I think that under -- he could be fired, if the reason for the firing was not based upon his having filed a complaint.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I know.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: If the reason --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Let's assume the employer says, look, I'm not firing you for filing the complaint at all; I'm firing you for refusing to work while -- during the period that -- while you're waiting for OSHA to come.
Could you fire him?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: All right, it's our view, yes, sir, that would be -- that would be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: -- not protected under OSHA.
Now, there may be protections under other legislation, but not under OSHA.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, then I take it your position -- why do you think the Solicitor General mischaracterizes your position, then, in their brief?
Because I thought I asked you whether he was free not to work while he's waiting for OSHA.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: It's our view that he is free not to work.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he's free not to work; you mean there is no slavery?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Right.
(Laughter)

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: The question of whether or not he retains his job security during that period of time, we feel Congress did not intend to regulate under this act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you don't have to -- you don't have to keep him as an employee, nor do you have to pay him while he's waiting for OSHA?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's our view; yes, sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Mann, you made reference to perhaps other protections, which I assume refers to the Labor-Management Relations Act.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's the one --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I assume it would be true, would it not, under that case involving a place of work that was too cold, that if three or four of these people got together and said, "None of us will work, because we all want you to remedy the situation..." in some way, that would be protected under the Labor Act.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I believe it would under the facts you quote, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the only issue really here, as I understand it, is whether one employee acting independently can refuse to work.
If he gets a few co-workers to agree with him, and they agree they're going to sacrifice pay for the period they don't work, that's the whole fight here, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, I believe there have been some recent decisions under -- by the National Labor Relations Board under the NLRA holding that a single employee's withdrawal may constitute protected activity under Section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act if it's a safety-related situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So if it's even --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the result is what?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: He doesn't get paid.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He doesn't get paid, and he's on strike, but he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he cannot be disciplined; is that the idea?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He cannot be disciplined, but he doesn't get paid.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So isn't the only question here is whether there -- there are two ways to -- I mean, whether he has an additional protection for the same right that the Labor Act already protects?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.
But I think it -- and the problem is, what is that additional protection?
Under the Secretary's view, that additional protection is, in effect, pay for not working.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he disclaims that.
He says, no.
He says -- that's how he distinguishes all this strike-with-pay legislative history.

He says, well, that's talking about paying him, and we are not contending -- in other words, if our opinion -- say you lose here, and we wrote an opinion that says that man is not entitled to be paid, would you be perfectly happy?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, I, certainly I would hope --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you didn't try to fire him, did you?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, we gave him a warning.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You just put a citation in his file, and you didn't give him another thing to do during that --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If all we said was, take the citation out of his file, and you don't have to pay him, then there isn't much of a fight here as I see it.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, I think there may be a fight, Your Honor, in this sense.

Our concern is that the OSHA Act attempts, we believe, to encourage employees to utilize the procedures under that act, and not resort to self-help; that the resort to self-help is defeating the objects of that act which are to try and eliminate safety hazards through cooperative efforts and through orderly procedures under the supervision of the Secretary.
Now, we feel that this regulation, to the extent that it is presently utilized by the Secretary, and interpreted, has the effect of encouraging employees to utilize self-help --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yeah, but they give up there -- they don't get paid when they do it.
I mean, that's a sort of a deterrent.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that you -- you've told us that at least under some Federal decisions that individual employee has a -- the freedom to do under the National Labor Relations Act.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He has the freedom to withdraw from work.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because of dangerous or intolerable conditions of some other kind.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he doesn't get paid?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He doesn't get paid.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.
But my brother Stevens, the hypothesis of his question was that he wouldn't get paid in this case, even if we disagreed with you.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: The Secretary takes the view in his brief, and I would point this out, that the employee's right is to be given alternate work.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If available.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: If available.
But the dynamics of a workplace, Your Honor, is that there will always be alternate work available, in any type of a reasonably sized industry.
That's going to always happen.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, wouldn't you have the same duty under the Labor Act?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Not if an employee goes on strike.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he just says, "I won't work because it's too cold or dangerous," or something?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He's out of the plant; he's on strike.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: There's no requirement under the Labor Act to provide him some alternate--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How do you read Judge Damon Keith's opinion for the Court of Appeals as requiring the employer to do what?
Pay him?
First of all, pay him?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I believe that Judge Keith's decision implies an obligation to pay the employee.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the way I read it too.
But it wasn't all that clear.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: During that period of time --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And certainly not to discipline them.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And to pay them?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: And to pay them, or find alternate work for them.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he doesn't spell it out, does he?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He doesn't spell that out, but he upholds the regulation which has that -- has that connotation to it, yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does it?
Does the regulation have it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: The Secretary in his brief repeatedly refers to the obligation to find alternate work if available.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's not --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I think he draws that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You mean alternate work at the same pay?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Alternate work at some pay; perhaps not the same pay.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: He doesn't elaborate that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I read these briefs pretty carefully, and I came away with a good many unanswered questions in my mind.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I did too.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that's the reason I'm asking you some of those questions.

Do you understand that the Court of Appeals opinion said that under this regulation, which of course the Court of Appeals held was a valid regulation under the statute, that the employer has an obligation, A, not to discipline -- that's certainly clear; B, do you think to pay?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because that's not clear, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: -- if he's not -- I believe what the Court of Appeals said is that the employer cannot discriminate against the employee.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What's that mean?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Under the Secretary's --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I mean, under the Labor Act, that simply means you can't fire him, because that's a protected union activity.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: But under Section 1977.12 of the Secretary's regulations, he defines discrimination in the broadest possible sense the deprivation of any perquisite of employment, or words to that effect.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does that mean pay for not work?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: And we believe it means pay for not work.
And that's exactly --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it's not clear, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: It's not clear.
But that's the position that the Secretary has been taking--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't it be argued that a day's pay is discipline?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: They're here to pay his discipline, that's --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't it be argued?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That could be argued.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: And that undoubtedly would be argued.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do you think on the first point-- or perhaps it was the second that was just propounded? What do you think the Sixth Circuit opinion means with respect to the pay?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I would read the Sixth Circuit's opinion to mean that--or could be construed to mean that an employee may not be discriminated against, either with respect to pay or any other term or condition of employment, if he refuses to work under the conditions posed by this regulation.
I believe that's how the lower Federal courts would probably construe that regulation, in the dynamics of a particular case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, does that mean pay or not?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: It means pay; and it means pay for this reason, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: While not working?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: While not working.
Consider the employer's options under these circumstances.

If the employee refuses to perform a job, and the employer agrees that the job should not be performed and reassigns him, to that extent, the employer is paying him but not getting the work done that the employee was hired for.
So that's, in a sense, a pay situation.
If the employer says, "No, I disagree with you.
I believe that job is safe."
Or, "I believe that I have taken sufficient steps to correct the problem, and therefore, I will either discipline you or require you to work that job."
Once an employer disciplines the employee, you automatically have a pay situation.
If the employee, on the other hand, were to actually just say, "I'm going on strike.
I'm exercising my rights under Section 7," then obviously, there's no pay situation there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, don't most collective bargaining contracts call for some provision for sick leave?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Most collective bargaining agreements call for some provision of sick leave -- or make some reference of that type, right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if a man simply failed to show up because he was hung over for the period of time that this man was -- refused to work?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, it would -- I -- you mean as a subterfuge for not working?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No; he was sick.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Oh.
Well, under those circumstances, depending on what his contract provided, he may or may not be paid.
Some do, and some don't.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that wouldn't be a form of discipline, would it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Denying him pay for not working, no, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In this case, your client, after these two employees refused to go on the screen, did what?
Said, you go home --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, our -- yes.
The supervisor asked them a couple of times to work, and they refused.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: There was a dialogue, and then --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But then there was a final refusal?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: There was a final refusal.
The matter was re-discussed in the personnel office.
And the personnel director directed the persons to go home --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But there was then a final refusal?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: And a final refusal.
They went home for the balance of the shift.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They went home at the direction of the employer?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct; and returned the following morning.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For the balance of the shift, and they didn't get paid for those hours.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in addition to that, they were disciplined.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in what way?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: They were issued a written warning; it was put in their file.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That was it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They weren't docked any pay for work they had done, or anything like that.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Oh, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Mann, may I suggest this approach, that the statute and regulations say there are certain kinds of things that the employee has a statutory right to do, such as file complaints.
And then there is a provision that if he does any of those things, there are certain things may not--he may not be disciplined for them.
Now, it would seem to me the question of whether it's discipline would be the same question whether he refused to work because he thought it was dangerous, or because he went and made a complaint.

Now, my question then is Supposing he didn't show up one morning, but instead went over to the OSHA Office to file a complaint; he had to sit in the waiting room all morning before they'd listen to him; he killed the whole day.
He showed up the next day.
Would you have a statutory obligation to pay him?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then, what's the difference?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's what I want to know.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Supposing he just doesn't work that day because he thinks it's too dangerous.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You'd have a statutory obligation not to discipline.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: We have a statutory obligation not to discipline him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I'm saying, if you failed to pay him, that's not discipline?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, but the reason --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why is it discipline in this case?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: The reason that it's not discipline is that he is not presenting himself for work, and he is merely exercising a right that he has under the statute.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, but if we say that's all he did here, then the consequence is the same.
He -- these two people are not presenting themselves for work when they say it's too dangerous for us to work.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, they are being -- well, the reason that they're going to be paid for not working is because they're being disciplined, or they're being assigned to some other job.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, the reason they're going to be paid for not working, you say?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: It's the disciplinary action that triggers the pay.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, no, now I -- in answer to Justice Stevens, you said that instead of coming to work and reporting in at the beginning of his shift, this employee had gone to the OSHA office in Marion, Ohio, to file a complaint, that under the statute, clearly you couldn't discipline him for that.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you further said that there's no requirement under the statute that you pay him for work not done.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now, what's the difference in this case?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Because the employee is being discipline.
In the case of the work refusal, he's being disciplined

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, but if the Solicitor General is right, all you had to do differently was just not put that piece of paper in his file.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's right, that's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just don't pay him.
And why wouldn't the case then be the same, and then there isn't this terrible consequence?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, the Solicitor has taken the position in this case that we had an--an additional obligation not only not to put the paper in his file, but find him an alternate work assignment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That wouldn't even be true if he were at the OSHA office, would it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, that wouldn't be true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where it was clearly under the statute.
Your only statutory duty is not to discipline him; isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then why would he have greater rights when the statutory is considerably more ambiguous?
And if it weren't so ambiguous, this case wouldn't be here.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, the obligation of the employer is not to discriminate against him, including imposition of discipline.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I have a little trouble.
What would you do if the man says, "Look, I just won't work."
And you say, "Well, you don't work, I won't pay."
Is that discipline?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That could be construed as discipline; that could be construed as discriminatory action.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's what I mean.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: If he had a right to refuse that job under --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I'm not talking -- I'm talking about this case.
What could you do other than what you did?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: I don't know what could have been done other than what we've done in this case, the issuance of discipline.
There was a dispute over the existence of a hazard, and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Number one, you couldn't pay him for not working.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you do pay him when he's on sick leave.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That may be the policy.
I'm not familiar with the sick leave policy, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, have they got a union contract?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Mann, may I suggest that, assuming there's a statutory right here, there are three possible answers on the remedy.
One is, you had to pay him even if he didn't work.
And you say that's what's implicitly required, and the other side says no.
Secondly, that you could stick a piece of paper in his file, and that's discipline.
And thirdly, that you had to give him another job.
Now it's conceivable that you didn't have to do any of those three things.
All you had to do was just say, "Well, we won't pay you.
We'll treat you just like you're on strike."
And that would recognize the statutory right, and avoid all the--it may well be that they granted a remedy they had no right to grant.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That would be an approach that could be taken.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And maybe that under -- that even though you're wrong, and that you are under the statute, the Secretary's regulation is a correct or allowable interpretation of the act, it may be that even so your only duty was not to put that piece of paper in his file.
And that's not at all clear in this case, either from your brief or from the Solicitor General's.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, I might --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or from the Court of Appeals opinion.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: And I might suggest that the ambiguities in the regulation itself tend to lend some problem there, too.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, the -- whether you could fire him or not is the same question as to whether you can put the piece of paper in his file.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And you think you should be able not only to put the piece of paper in his file, but to fire him?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, I think any form of discipline that's --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, any form.
So it's just not a piece of paper.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it's discipline.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It's discipline; any kind of discipline.
Like getting rid of him.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But then there might be a grievance.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: There might be a grievance, or he might make a claim under the National Labor Relations Act, or some other contract.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It would seem to me that you've conceded that the National Labor Relations Act would prevent you from firing him.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: If he engaged in concerted activity and went on strike.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you earlier told me just one man alone could do this under the --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there are some cases, you say?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: There have been some recent decisions in that area.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Has the Board taken a position on that, or is that just a -- is that just a 301 action?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: No, the Labor Board, I believe, in a case called Alleluia Cushion has taken a position that there's a right to engage in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On the other hand, you could just -- the man might have to work, and he gets killed; it wouldn't hurt you at all.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, we would expect that if the employee was concerned that there was an imminent --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, if he had to work.
And that broke again, and he died.
That wouldn't cost you anything.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Well, we would hope that wouldn't occur, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You just have workmen's comp; you've already paid that.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: We feel that the salutary effects of this act are going to be lost if we're litigating in Federal court these kinds of decisions over discriminatory or disciplinary actions, which really never lead to the ultimate question of the existence or non-existence of hazards, or what is needed to abate them.
The only question that's resolved by this type of litigation is whether or not discipline was proper.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the issue was what was in the minds --

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: What was in the minds.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: --of the employees, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Contrast that with the Section 13 procedures.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Were they in good faith, and was it reasonable, and so on.

turn.speaker: robert_e_mann
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Mann
turn.text: Right.
In the Section 13 procedures prescribed by Congress, the issue before the Court is whether there's a hazard or not; that's the issue to be resolved.
I see my time is up.
Thank you, Your Honor.

section.heading: Argument of Wade H. McCree, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

This case presents the question, whether Section 11(c)(1) of OSHA, as interpreted by the Secretary of Labor in 29 CFR 1977.12(b)(2) prohibits an employer from retaliating against an employee who refuses to perform particular assigned tasks when the following conditions exist.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now before you go off -- I had thought that that wasn't the issue at all; that the issue was, whether or not the Secretary had any power at all to issue 1977.12(b)(2).

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that may --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or whether or not that was contrary to the statute.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, that may be another way of expressing the same thought.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it may be; may be.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Clearly, this is an interpretative regulation; it's not a legislative regulation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the question is --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And the question is, does the statute --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- is it an authorized interpretative regulation.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Precisely.
Does the statute afford a worker the right that the Secretary delineated in this carefully drawn interpretative regulation.

And this regulation provides that he may not be discriminated against if he refuses to perform a particular assigned task when the following conditions occur first, in good faith; second, he concludes that there is a real danger of death or serious injury confronting him; three, under circumstances that a reasonable person would so conclude; four, and the urgency of the situation afforded insufficient time to eliminate the danger through resort to the regular statutory enforcement channels; five, he also sought if possible from his employer, but without success, a correction of the dangerous condition; and six, he had no reasonable alternative.

We suggest that under that very narrow concurrence of circumstances that the act, by necessary implication, affords this right to the employee, which under Section 11(c)(1), which is the anti-discrimination provision of the statute, protects him from discrimination on the part of his employer.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, what do you think that means, protects him from discrimination?
It certainly means, if you're correct, that he's protected from any disciplinary action, being fired or anything less than that.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think that's clear.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But does it mean that he's entitled to be paid for time that he doesn't work, when he goes off, unlike a striker?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No, I do not believe it entitles him to pay unless, in an almost equivalent situation, another employee would be entitled to pay.
I interpret discrimination to mean to treat him differently from the way someone else--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because of what he does.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --in an almost similar situation would be following.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what's a similar situation?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, why would another employee ever do that?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, for example, suppose he agreed -- suppose an employee recognized an situation as presenting an imminent risk of death or serious bodily harm, and objectively it existed --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And all these conditions existed.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --and he believed it in good faith, and so forth.
Except, the only difference being, the foreman agreed with him.
The foreman said, "You're right.
You don't have to work until we correct that."
Now, if that employee received pay while the matter was being corrected, then I would think this employee would be entitled to pay.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But only under that sort of --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Under that kind of situation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Only -- you can't be treated other than other similarly situated employees are treated.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And I said, almost similarly situated, because there is this one minor --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But your similarity is limited to OSHA-type situations, when you're talking about discriminating.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
If he--if it were an economic strike, or something of that sort, certainly he would not be entitled to pay.
But he would have to be treated as another employee would.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I probe a little bit about what kind of similarity we're talking about?

Are you saying that if, in a given plant, an employee comes in, and it's manifestly terribly dangerous for him to work, and he says, "I don't want to work until this is corrected," and the company says, "Okay, you don't have to work, and you'll be paid," is it then similar if the next day there's another situation in which there is--not nearly as clear that it's dangerous; it's an entirely different part of the plant and all the rest; and the supervisor says, "I don't agree with you; I think you should work."
He refuses.
And the company does not pay him.
And he comes in and says, "Well, you paid the other man."
They say, "Well, that was much more dangerous, and we agreed with you there, but we don't agree with you here."
Does he have to pay -- in other words, does the company set a precedent that it must always pay everytime it agrees to pay one?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No, I would think the company reserves its right to make a distinction between situations.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And the test would be this If a company refused to pay on your second day situation --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- then the employee under the statute would have to ask the Secretary --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- to bring an action for him to relieve him of the consequences of the discrimination, if it was discrimination.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And it would be discrimination if they paid the man on the night shift but not the man on the day shift --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- or something like that.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We would hope the Secretary would make -- would discriminate, too, and would look carefully and decide whether to bring this.

And if the Secretary ultimately decided to bring it, the burden would be on the Secretary to prove that the employee's refusal to work was within the narrow circumstances in the interpretative regulation that the Secretary established.
We suggest in our brief that the entire structure of the statute requires us to infer such a right, because the statute to begin with, looked at as a whole, is prophylactic and not compensatory.
It begins with the purpose stated of affording every man and woman in the workforce a safe place to work, and it isn't couched in terms of recompensing him after an accident has happened.
And we suggest that a statute that has that general design must necessarily permit him to refuse to work where his life is imperilled, or where he's subjected to serious imminent bodily harm.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, actually, that's not -- I'm not criticizing you for making that argument.
But the issue here is considerably narrower, isn't it?
And that is, whether or not this interpretative regulation is within the terms of a specific part of this statute?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's not explicit.
It's implicit.
We must argue that it's implicit in the language the Congress employed.
But when the language is read as a whole --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is, 10(c)(1).

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- it's a necessary part of the statute.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what's specifically involved, isn't it?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, sir.
I quarrel with my brother, Mr. Mann, in this respect.
We submit that there is no question about the two employees here coming within the narrow strictures of this described right.

I think, and there's no question about it as I read the district court's opinion, the district court found that he would be entitled to be free from discrimination but for the fact, as the district court determined, the statute didn't afford him that right.
And the Court of Appeals found that there was ample support for that finding, and expressly adopted the -- or confirmed the findings of fact and conclusions of law.
And so this Court has at this point the pure legal question of statutory interpretation Does OSHA afford a narrowly -- this narrowly described right?
And we suggest it is -- in our brief--as we look at the several provisions of the statute, that it must necessarily must have intended this to be.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course, as you say, Mr. Solicitor General, your brother says that the Secretary has gone even beyond his own regulation in this particular case.
That's in his reply brief, and I think it's also in his brief.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
I don't understand his assertion --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you're just telling us that you disagree with that?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- that he's gone beyond it.
I don't know in what respect he contends he's gone beyond it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I thought I understood what he was saying.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And -- well, I read his brief as saying the same thing, but I don't know in what respect he does.
Because the court found all of these elements there.
And certainly there isn't any question about the ample evidentiary support for it.
I was very much interested in the physical attributes of this plant.
There are some not very revealing photographs unfortunately; they're part of the record.

I think if the Court would like to see those in the record, it could see visually this artificial floor made of mesh, and it could see, indeed, that the June 28th fatal plunge isn't very difficult to imagine, nor is it difficult to credit the employees with good faith and a reasonable apprehension of danger, to walk across that mesh.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, one thing -- back up a minute -- in a case just like this where the man says, "Look, one or two or three people have fallen through there, and I'm not going up there."
And the supervisor says, "Well, you've got to go."
He says, "I won't go."
He says, "Well, go home."
Now, suppose he just stays home.
Suppose nobody does anything from then on.
What happens?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I would think -- I would think we'd have to work out some rule of reason.
He certainly cannot remain home and expect to be paid.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's my point.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Again, I say, we'd have to see what would happen if the foreman had agreed with him.

If the foreman had agreed with him and said, "All right, you go home and show up tomorrow morning," then this man, too, would have the duty -- who unilaterally decided the risk was something he shouldn't endure.
He'd have to show up the next day.
And if they could find him alternative work, he would have to perform that, unless it would violate the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But there are some plants where you couldn't find alternative work.
For example, the asbestos plants.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if he -- if the plant -- another analogy suggests itself.
Suppose the machinery broke down at the plant.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Nobody could work.
Well, they don't pay under those circumstances either.
And so this is not a strike-with-pay situation at all.
The very narrowly drawn right that the Secretary recognized in this regulation was just to prevent a tragedy from occurring, and to allow the regular procedures of OSHA to run their normal course.
We would expect him --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, on that suggestion, supposing -- I'd like to ask you the same question I asked Mr. Mann -- if he had been concerned, and in the morning got up and went to the OSHA office.
It took him all day to file his complaint so he didn't show up at all for a given day.
And it's clearly protected by the statute because he's making a complaint.
Would the employer have a statutory duty to pay him for that day?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think he might, because this is -- and he might.
This is an express right that's given.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What's the discrimination?
He didn't show up for work.
So you don't pay people who don't work.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, but the statute here --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There's no discipline.

No paper in the file, no discharge, no -- nothing hanging over that -- he came back the next day, and they say, "Gee, I'm glad you called it to the inspector's attention, because we'd like to know whether they think it's too dangerous."
They're just as nice as they can be to him.
How could you say there's discrimination because they don't pay him for a day he doesn't work?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, because this is an express right that's given him under the act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's a right to be paid -- to be paid for making a complaint?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in other words, it's a right to file complaints and to initiate the statutory machinery for investigation and remedying --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it seems to me that if you take that position, that he's entitled to be paid that day, and you also say he has a right just not to work for a day because it's too dangerous, equally he ought to be paid for that day.
Therefore, it seems to me, you are arguing for a right to strike without--with pay.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I really don't think so.
And I think the two situations are distinguishable in this fashion.
The statute encourages the filing of a report, and bringing into operating--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: There's a statutory right to do that, but you're arguing there's a statutory right to sit down, too.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: All right.
But he may have to spend all day to get the attention of the OSHA inspector.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: He doesn't have to remain all day to get down off that mesh.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If there's no alternate work?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And once he's down from that mesh, and he's no longer in a place of peril, then he's subject to the orders of the foreman at the workplace.
The foreman can put him on another job.

These are maintenance people in this case, and it was estimated that they spent about 15 hours a week -- I take it that's out of a 40-hour week -- working on this overhead mesh, retrieving stock that fell from the conveyor belt, and getting rid of dripping oil.
And the other portion of the 40-hour week, the other 35 hours were spent -- or 25 hours, I guess -- were spent in other maintenance tasks.
So as soon as he got down from the place of peril, then it would seem that the authority of the foreman would he reestablished.
Whereas, the worker who had gone out to the OSHA office, and had to sit in the waiting room, he couldn't do anything until he reached the OSHA inspector.
After that, he would have a duty to come back.

In Marshall v. Barlow's, Inc. in the -- I think the dissenting opinion authored by Your Honor, the statement of the -- the quotation appears, "The number of inspections which it would be desirable to have made will undoubtedly, for an unforseeable period, exceed the capacity of the inspection force."
That was footnote 6 in the dissenting opinion, and I think that that suggests that there might -- require some additional time to be spent in the waiting room.
And that's the way I would try to distinguish those cases.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I just don't see how that -- that really answers my problem about why, if there's the same statutory right in both of the hypothetical cases, in one case you say he gets pay and the other one, you say he doesn't.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, because -- because the exercise of the right will take longer in one case than it will in the other.
And it seems to me that he's protected while he exercises the right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But what he's protected against is discipline or discrimination.
It just doesn't seem to me that it fits the definition of discrimination or discipline to say, "I'm not going to pay you for days you don't work."

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I know I'm repeating myself --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, I guess I am, too.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- but my best answer is, that he's protected while he does what the statute gives him permission to do.
He's not protected against discrimination after that time.
As soon as he's --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I agree, he's protected in both cases.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- made the report, he has to come back.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The question is whether the -- when the employer doesn't pay, why is it discrimination in one case and not the other?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He's protected in both?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- I suppose a further answer is, in order to vindicate the right to be free from discrimination, he's going to have to ask the Secretary to bring an action for him.
And maybe this is one of those instances where, on a case-by-case basis, some of these lacunae in the statutory scheme are just going to have to be worked out.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, General McCree, would you go so far as to say that not only in his trip to the OSHA office, but perhaps in the two or three days he spends testifying in the district court in Toledo, he's also entitled to be paid?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm not prepared to say he may not be.
But I'm suggesting that if he tries to extend it beyond what the statute -- the authorization of the statute gives him, then he is not entitled to pay; of that I'm certain.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if the employer's policy with respect to employees is to pay them only if they work, then somebody who goes to the OSHA office or goes to Toledo to testify is not entitled to pay, is he?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That may not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because it's not discrimination against him for exercising his rights under the act, his conceded rights under the act.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That may very well be the resolution that a court would make.
But I suggest that's not before us.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, isn't that the logical resolution for any court to make?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I say --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: A single, even-handed policy of the employer is simply not to pay people if they don't work.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I would say, it is a logical--a logical distinction.
If I may shift --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I mean, subject to vacation and sick pay and all the rest of it.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --into another area, we speak about citizens performing their civic duty.
Some states have statutes --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, but it's a statute.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --that require payment--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For jury duty.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: --for jury duty.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but it's a matter of statute.
In the absence of any statute.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, this statute may, by implication, do that.
And I'm not prepared -- that's not before us in any event today; I don't think it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it really is, in many ways.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: In a sense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because it seems to me that you and your brother argue about something that now you say is not before us.
I had understood that your position, and indeed, that Judge --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Keith; Judge Keith.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- yes, Damon Keith's opinion for the Sixth Circuit implied that this person was entitled to be paid.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's the way I understood the -- I though that was one of the issues between you.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm not certain -- and I would like to look at his opinion more carefully.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, Mr. Solicitor General, do you think now, having listened to your colleague and having said what you're said, that you are in agreement on pay, at least with respect to non-waiting time in OSHA office?
If he just says, "I'm going home today."

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: On that, I agree, he is not entitled to pay.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that is -- you're together on that.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think so; I think we are.
I think he is entitled to be treated no differently from any other employee under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: But I have to say, I'm not certain that that would be so if he exercised one of the rights expressly given him under the statute.
The Congress may have intended that.
It would seem quite consistent with a policy to encourage reports, to promote safety, to make it possible--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is it your position, Mr. Solicitor General, to say -- you are arguing that the unexpressed, implicit right is just as important as the expressed right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And yet you are suggesting that the remedy for violating the express right is more stern than the remedy for violating the unexpressed right.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It doesn't seem to me the statute -- that makes the statute very consistent.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I have failed to communicate a distinction that appears valid to me.
And it apparently has some infirmities, because it doesn't appear valid to you.
But it seems to me that the right to refuse work --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- is exercised in a short period of time.
He just says, "I'm getting down from this mesh before I fall through to my death."

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And as soon as he reaches the floor, then, he has removed himself from the danger of harm.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then the question --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And he is subject then to the foreman's instruction "Well, all right, get a broom, you're a maintenance person, and sweep the floor."
"Get a mop, clean up the oil."
Or something of that sort.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or the foreman might say, "This was your job on the shift; go home."

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If you don't want to do this job --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or he says, "All the other maintenance people are doing all the other jobs, so there's nothing more for you today to do today."

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And then doesn't he get in exactly the same position as the man who went to the OSHA office and had to kill the day because it took the whole day?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I would analogize him more to the person whose machine broke down.
And if his -- if the machine broke down, and there wasn't anything else to do because everybody else was working on every available machine, and they said, "You have to go home."

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but in one case, the employee doesn't work because the employer doesn't have work that, in effect, was promised to him; he promises him a machine to work on.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In the other two cases -- both the office case and the dangerous case -- the employee isn't working because he's exercising what you describe as a statutory right.
And then you're saying, one statutory right has -- even though it's the same one sentence in the statute -- the remedy differs in the two cases.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, perhaps --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You may be right.
I'll reflect on it, certainly, because I have the same regard for your views as you so kindly express with respect to mine.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
I would like to suggest in any event that this isn't before us at this time for a decision.
Because if this Court decides that there is a right, as described by the Secretary in the challenged interpretative regulation, that's what this lawsuit is about.
Now, what --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
